item.title: exam1 #15
item.description:
15. Inserting the integers 1, 2, 3, 5, and 4 into an empty red-black tree, in the order given, yields how many recolorings, single rotations, and double rotations, respectively? Don’t forget to color the root black, if need be. 

Im getting © none of the answers are correct being that it takes only 4 recolorings, 1 single rotate, and 1 double rotate. Am I doing enough recoloring?
item.content:encoded:
15. Inserting the integers 1, 2, 3, 5, and 4 into an empty red-black tree, in the order given, yields how many recolorings, single rotations, and double rotations, respectively? Don’t forget to color the root black, if need be. 

Im getting © none of the answers are correct being that it takes only 4 recolorings, 1 single rotate, and 1 double rotate. Am I doing enough recoloring?

item.title: Lusthian style?
item.description:
Quote:Consider a proof, by strong induction and using Lusthian style, to show that the above statement is true.
Can someone tell me what is Lusthian style? Never heard about that.
item.content:encoded:
Quote:Consider a proof, by strong induction and using Lusthian style, to show that the above statement is true.
Can someone tell me what is Lusthian style? Never heard about that.

item.title: exam1.pdf #20
item.description: For number 20 on the exam1.pdf, I'm not sure how to interpret the question. If we delete 5, we have to swap it up to parent until root then extract min (I think). Then we call extract min which gets rid of 5 (which is set to negative infinity) and promotes all the children of 5 up to the root list. At this point do we need answer the question and choose the subheap root for 6? Or do we finish the extract min (which calls to the fixer function I think) and combine same order heaps in the root list and then answer the question? I get two different answers depending on this.
item.content:encoded: For number 20 on the exam1.pdf, I'm not sure how to interpret the question. If we delete 5, we have to swap it up to parent until root then extract min (I think). Then we call extract min which gets rid of 5 (which is set to negative infinity) and promotes all the children of 5 up to the root list. At this point do we need answer the question and choose the subheap root for 6? Or do we finish the extract min (which calls to the fixer function I think) and combine same order heaps in the root list and then answer the question? I get two different answers depending on this.

item.title: 2x1 = 1x2?
item.description: For our notes page, is it ok if we use two one-sided sheets instead of one two-sided sheet? Whenever I tried printing two-sided in the library, it was completely illegible.
item.content:encoded: For our notes page, is it ok if we use two one-sided sheets instead of one two-sided sheet? Whenever I tried printing two-sided in the library, it was completely illegible.

item.title: Polynomialy Greater/Lesser
item.description: It seems like polynomial greater/lesser means that there is a number Epsilon that can be added or subtracted to one number which is already greater/less than another term and the sum/diff will still be greater/less than the other term. Is this right? Also could you give examples of things that are greater but not polynomialy greater/lesser but not polynomialy lesser?
item.content:encoded: It seems like polynomial greater/lesser means that there is a number Epsilon that can be added or subtracted to one number which is already greater/less than another term and the sum/diff will still be greater/less than the other term. Is this right? Also could you give examples of things that are greater but not polynomialy greater/lesser but not polynomialy lesser?

item.title: Masters Recurrence Theorem Questions
item.description:
The questions I am referring to are from this PDF : http://beastie.cs.ua.edu/concepts/cs/al/recurrences.pdf

General Questions about Masters Recurrence Theorem: 

Considering this form : T(n) = aT( n b ) + f(n) .


1. Are all these valid f(n) ? Means can we apply masters recurrence theorem on it? 
         f(n) :   n^n,  2^n,  n!, log n , n/logn , n^3/logn

2. Is the equation : T(n) = 2T(n − 2) + n  valid?  I think not because b !> 1

 3. Could you explain or could you give an example of an  equation  that would fall between two cases?  


Specific Questions : 

#47 : In terms of the master recurrence theorem, where does the equation T(n) = 2T( n / 4 ) + n 0.51 fall?
         
        So, here  n^log b(a)  =>  n^log4(2) =>  n^0.5

                  and f(n) = n^0.51 
  
        I know that   n^0.5 < n^0.51 , but would be the ans here? 
    
      what about this case : n^1.57   and   n^2? 

In general, If the difference between n^log b(a) and f(n) is just 0.1 or less than 1, do we assume that they both are equal? 


#44,45  :  What would be the right ans?
item.content:encoded:
The questions I am referring to are from this PDF : http://beastie.cs.ua.edu/concepts/cs/al/recurrences.pdf

General Questions about Masters Recurrence Theorem: 

Considering this form : T(n) = aT( n b ) + f(n) .


1. Are all these valid f(n) ? Means can we apply masters recurrence theorem on it? 
         f(n) :   n^n,  2^n,  n!, log n , n/logn , n^3/logn

2. Is the equation : T(n) = 2T(n − 2) + n  valid?  I think not because b !> 1

 3. Could you explain or could you give an example of an  equation  that would fall between two cases?  


Specific Questions : 

#47 : In terms of the master recurrence theorem, where does the equation T(n) = 2T( n / 4 ) + n 0.51 fall?
         
        So, here  n^log b(a)  =>  n^log4(2) =>  n^0.5

                  and f(n) = n^0.51 
  
        I know that   n^0.5 < n^0.51 , but would be the ans here? 
    
      what about this case : n^1.57   and   n^2? 

In general, If the difference between n^log b(a) and f(n) is just 0.1 or less than 1, do we assume that they both are equal? 


#44,45  :  What would be the right ans?

item.title: First Exam Collab Sheet
item.description:
Find it here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1...sp=sharing

Please don't delete any answers, even if you think they're wrong. Just place them in the next cell to the right, possibly with an explanation. No answers on this sheet are guarunteed to be correct, so use your best judgement.
item.content:encoded:
Find it here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1...sp=sharing

Please don't delete any answers, even if you think they're wrong. Just place them in the next cell to the right, possibly with an explanation. No answers on this sheet are guarunteed to be correct, so use your best judgement.
